item.title: Welcome to Fellowship of the Flux
item.description:
Welcome to Fellowship of the Flux! We’re excited to share our mission of advancing the art of learning to solder through community outreach, education, and resource sharing.

Our Story

Fellowship of the Flux began in Kansas City with a simple belief: everyone should have the opportunity to learn soldering skills in a supportive, hands-on environment. What started as volunteer-run workshops at local cybersecurity conferences like BSides KC and MakerFaire KC has grown into a regional resource for STEM education.

item.description:

Through partnerships with conferences, schools, maker spaces, and community organizations, we’ve created a scalable model for electronics education that serves learners from age 8 to 80+.

Program Goals

Educational Excellence

  • Hands-on Learning: Direct experience with professional-grade equipment and real projects
  • Safety First: Comprehensive safety training and protocols for all participants
  • Skill Building: Progressive curriculum from basic techniques to advanced applications
  • Confidence Development: Creating positive first experiences with electronics and making

Community Impact

  • Accessibility: Bringing education to underserved communities and rural areas
  • Diversity: Welcoming learners of all backgrounds, ages, and experience levels
  • Sustainability: Training local volunteers to continue programs independently
  • Network Building: Connecting learners with ongoing maker communities and resources

Organizational Growth

  • Volunteer Development: Training passionate educators and community leaders

item.title: Building Modern Electronics Education Platforms
item.description:
Building Modern Electronics Education Platforms

Creating effective online learning experiences for hands-on skills like soldering presents unique challenges. How do you teach tactile skills through digital interfaces? How do you maintain engagement without physical presence? At Fellowship of the Flux, we’ve been exploring these questions while building our comprehensive learning platform.

The Challenge of Digital Hands-On Education

Traditional electronics education relies heavily on in-person instruction, immediate feedback, and physical demonstration. Translating this to digital formats requires innovative approaches that complement rather than replace hands-on learning.

item.title: Essential Soldering Techniques and Best Practices
item.description:
Essential Soldering Techniques and Best Practices

After five years of teaching soldering workshops with Fellowship of the Flux, I’ve seen every mistake imaginable and learned what techniques consistently produce the best results. Whether you’re just starting out or looking to refine your skills, these tips will help you create reliable, professional-quality solder joints.

Fundamental Principles

Heat Management

The most critical aspect of good soldering is proper heat management. Your soldering iron should be hot enough to melt solder quickly but not so hot that it damages components or PCBs.

item.title: About Fellowship of the Flux
item.description:
About Fellowship of the Flux

Our Story

Fellowship of the Flux began in Kansas City with a simple idea: everyone should have the opportunity to learn soldering skills in a supportive, hands-on environment. What started as volunteer-run workshops at local cybersecurity conferences like BSides KC and MakerFaire KC has grown into a regional resource for STEM education.

Our name playfully references the Fellowship of the Ring, emphasizing our belief that learning is a shared journey. Just as flux enables solder to flow and create strong connections, we help knowledge flow between experienced makers and eager learners, creating lasting connections in our community.

item.title: Basic Through-Hole Soldering
item.description:
Overview

Through-hole soldering is the foundation of electronics assembly. In this tutorial, you’ll learn to create professional-quality solder joints that are both mechanically and electrically sound.

Learning Objectives

By the end of this tutorial, you will be able to:

  • Set up your soldering station properly
  • Create consistent, reliable solder joints
  • Identify and correct common soldering defects
  • Solder various through-hole components safely

Prerequisites

Before starting this tutorial, you should:

  • Have basic knowledge of electronic components
  • Understand electrical safety principles
  • Have read our Soldering Safety Guide

item.title: Build Your Own Soldering Lab
item.description:
Build Your Own Soldering Lab

Want to create your own portable soldering lab for educational workshops? Learn from our experience building and refining our mobile setup over years of community events.

Why Build a Portable Lab?

Advantages of a Dedicated Setup

  • Consistent quality - Same professional equipment every time
  • Efficient setup - Organized systems reduce event preparation time
  • Safety focus - Purpose-built for educational environments
  • Scalability - Easily expand or adapt for different event sizes
  • Professional appearance - Builds confidence with event organizers

Investment Considerations

  • Initial cost: $3,000-8,000 for a 10-20 station lab
  • Ongoing expenses: Consumables, maintenance, storage
  • Time investment: Setup, training, event coordination
  • Storage requirements: Secure space for equipment between events

item.title: Simple Audio Amplifier
item.description:
Project Overview

Build a simple but effective audio amplifier using the popular LM386 IC. This project teaches analog circuit construction while creating a useful device that can amplify audio from phones, computers, or other sources.

What You’ll Learn

  • Analog circuit principles: Understanding amplifier operation and design
  • Audio circuit construction: Working with audio signals and impedance matching
  • Component selection: Choosing appropriate capacitors and resistors for audio
  • Enclosure work: Professional finishing and assembly techniques
  • Testing procedures: Measuring gain, frequency response, and distortion

Difficulty Level

item.title: Simple LED Flasher Circuit
item.description:
Project Overview

The LED flasher is a classic first electronics project that teaches fundamental soldering skills while creating a useful and satisfying result. You’ll build a circuit using the versatile 555 timer IC that makes an LED blink at a regular interval.

What You’ll Learn

  • Component identification: Recognizing resistors, capacitors, and ICs
  • Polarity awareness: Proper orientation of polarized components
  • Soldering technique: Creating reliable through-hole solder joints
  • Circuit testing: Using a multimeter to verify your work
  • Troubleshooting: Finding and fixing common assembly errors

Difficulty Level

This project is rated as beginner because it:

item.description:

Learning Objectives

  • Handle and place SMD components accurately
  • Solder 0603 and 0805 passive components
  • Use drag soldering technique for SOIC packages
  • Apply flux effectively for SMD work
  • Troubleshoot common SMD soldering problems

item.title: Soldering Safety Guide
item.description:
Introduction

Safety should always be your top priority when soldering. This comprehensive guide covers essential safety practices, proper workspace setup, and emergency procedures to ensure you can solder safely and confidently.

Personal Protective Equipment (PPE)

Eye Protection

Safety Glasses

  • Required for all soldering work
  • Protect against flux splatter and metal particles
  • Choose wrap-around style for maximum protection
  • Anti-fog coating recommended for comfort

Magnifying Equipment

  • Reduces eye strain during detailed work
  • LED-illuminated magnifiers provide better visibility
  • Adjustable arm magnifiers offer flexibility

Hand Protection

When to Use Gloves
